date: stated on May 10, 2011 in an interview on NBC's "Today" show:
title: John Bohner says that Bush tax cuts created 8 million jobs over 10 years.
text: :: During an interview on the NBC programme today, John Bohner, Speaker of the House of Representatives, presented some statistics on job creation to highlight the tax cuts approved by President George W. Bush in 2001 and 2003. The host said to Bohner, "You're talking about job creation. When the taxes were reduced under the Bush era in 2001, unemployment in the country was 4.5 per cent. Today it's 9%, just less than 10%. So why does Bush's period of tax cuts create jobs? Bohner replied that tax cuts "have created about 8 million jobs over the first 10 years of their existence. We lost about 5 million of those jobs during this recession." Several readers suggested that we examine Bohner's statistics. So we did. Bohanner's statement actually has several problems. One is the question of whether tax cuts have already caused job growth; more so later. First, we'll point out something more fundamental -- that Bohanner's timeline is canceled. The first tax reduction was approved in June 2001, so we have not reached a full 10 years since the first reduction was issued, and the second round of reductions is only eight years old. We will give Bohner the most generous possible criteria - from the signing of the first tax reduction in June 2001 to the peak of employment before the contraction, which came in January 2008. (When we called Bohner's office, they confirmed that this was the comparison he was thinking about.) We have moved to data from the Bureau of Labour Statistics - specifically, figures from the current series of employment statistics, calculated using a broad survey of employer salary data. The figures are as follows: June 2001: 132,047,000 people are employed in January 2008: 137,996,000 people work an increase over the six-and-a-half-year period: 5,949,000 people, or approximately 6 million jobs - well below 8 million Pohner mentioned. Let us now turn to jobs that were lost during the recession. Once again, we calculated the figures in the most favourable way for Bohner - from the peak of employment (January 2008) to the lowest point (February 2010). These figures are: January 2008: 137,996,000 people work in February 2010: 129,246,000 people work in decline during almost the biennium: 8,750,000 people have lost, equivalent to approximately 9 million jobs - almost double what Bohner said today. What's going on? When we arrived at Bohner's office, spokesperson Michael Steele presented a different set of numbers -- the numbers we identified were from a different set of BLS statistics, known as the current population survey. The figures from the data of the Community Statistics Service are the result of a smaller survey of individuals and families. It is best known for producing the widely followed national unemployment rate, but the data also include an estimate of the initial number of working Americans, which was used by Bohner. The figures for the same periods as those considered above are as follows: June 2001: 136,873,000 persons were employed in January 2008: 146,407,000 persons were employed over six and a half years: 9,534,000 persons were employed in January 2008: 146,407,000 persons were employed in February 2010: 138,698,000 persons were employed over a period of approximately two years: 7,709,000 people were reduced until Bohner, using company employment figures, de facto underestimated the value of jobs created after Bush ' s tax cuts, instead of overestimating them. The number of jobs lost during the recession was closer to the CPS number than the CES number. In other words, using one set of data, Bohner is moving away, and using another, it is closer. What's up? For the periods studied, it appears that the different data sets have resulted in significant differences in the number of jobs created and lost. While both statisticians have advantages and disadvantages, the standard statistical classification figures "usually prefer when talking about job growth or loss," as Stacy Standish, a BLS spokesman, said. And there's this problem: what if we use Bohner's number ten years instead of increasing the number of jobs for six and a half years? Over the full 10 years, employment has actually declined by more than 1 million jobs using the figures for the central civil service and has risen by 2.8 million according to the figures for the civil service. In both cases, both figures are significantly lower than Bohner ' s career gains for the full 10-year period. First, under the most common labour measurement standard - CS data - Boehner ' s claim is significantly exaggerated. Second, while Bohner is closer when using a different statistical, it is more accurate if he uses a much different period of time than he mentioned in the interview. Third, his suggestion that tax cuts are primarily responsible for subsequent job growth is controversial at best (it indicates that job growth is modest compared to previous administrations).
